text:
To reply to @AlexandreAbraham 's comment: in a sense, yes, it's a bit of a quick hack. However, it's a very light modification and it makes the code work like the user expects it: asking the user to do fit(['fmri.nii']) is not good. In addition, the current error

In the long run, maybe we should think about this in the same time as when we do the globbiing.

I have made sure that strings are well handle (as per @AlexandreAbraham 's remark).
Rebased branch. Waiting for tests to finish.
Can I haz merge?
Fixed. Thanks
CI is green. Merging
This should work if rebased.
I can merge and fix the small stuff directly into master or you can fix it now.
I'll just wait for CI to go green, just to be sure, and I'll merge!
LGTM
Looks good.

I'm a bit afraid of this change as we don't really have control on the input. For example, with imgs="test.nii", this will not work as strings are iterable. And I'm sure that we can find other weird cases. This is why NiftiStuffMasker are declined in Single and Multi flavors: accepting any dimensionality of data was too messy.

Plus documentation is not updated.

I would go for feeding ['test.nii'] to canica for single subject and postponing this behavior for later when we will have time to think it through. Apart from that, +1 for merge.

title: title

text:
Hi, 
I am getting this error

```
>  File "/Users/Ralf/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nilearn/plotting/displays.py", line 659, in _show_colorbar
>     bounds = np.linspace(norm.vmin, norm.vmax, our_cmap.N)
> 
> AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'N'

```

This is my code 

```
display = plotting.plot_connectome(delta_edge, 
                         networks_coords[3:], 
                         display_mode = 'y',
                         node_color= networks_cols[3:],  
                         colorbar=True,                         
                         edge_cmap = 'Blues',
                         edge_vmin = 0,
                         edge_vmax = 0.075,
                         annotate = False,
                         );        
```

All works well without the custom edge_cmap. If that is intended behavior, all is fine, but perhaps one wants to make a note. Thanks, Ralf.
title: colorbar in plot_connectome with different edge_cmap
colorbar in plot_connectome with different edge_cmap

text:
You are right, we should accept colormap names. In the meantime, you can use this workaround:

``` python
from matplotlib.cm import get_cmap

display = plotting.plot_connectome(delta_edge, 
                         networks_coords[3:], 
                         display_mode = 'y',
                         node_color= networks_cols[3:],  
                         colorbar=True,                         
                         edge_cmap = get_cmap('Blues'),
                         edge_vmin = 0,
                         edge_vmax = 0.075,
                         annotate = False,
                         );       
```
nice! thanks so much. Best ralf

text:
I agree that the strategy is hard to describe. Instead of describing it, I think that you should at least state what is the purpose of the "auto" keyword:

The default strategy, corresponding to "auto", computes a threshold that seeks to minimize (yet not eliminate completely) the overlap between maps for a better display.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/plotting/img_plotting.py')

text:
It is a bit convoluted. I would simplify:

If None, no threshold is applied.

Even better:

If None, a very small threshold is applied to remove numerical noise from the maps background.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/plotting/img_plotting.py')

text:
> to remove numerical noise from the maps background

A bit technical for user. I would keep this: "If None, no threshold is applied."

title: title

text:
NaNs occur frequently, e.g. after SPM preprocessing.
As a general rule, NaNs should not be ignored, but has a deleterious effect in low-level such functions. I propose to impute by 0's in the add_edges() function, but leaves Nans otherwise.
title: add_edges() fails when there is a NaN in the image
add_edges() fails when there is a NaN in the image

title: title

text:
I just realized that concat_imgs wants the nifti items to concat to exhibit a same dimension. The code below tried to concatenate `all_frames` (4D) and `block_mean_frame` (3D), yet failed. Perhaps we could improve the error message at this point. What do you guys think?

`````` python
In [158]: all_frames = concat_imgs([all_frames, block_mean_frame])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
DimensionError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-158-9e4d213099ce> in <module>()
----> 1 all_frames = concat_imgs([all_frames, block_mean_frame])

/home/parietal/dbzdok/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nilearn-0.1.5.dev0-py2.7.egg/nilearn/_utils/niimg_conversions.pyc in concat_niimgs(niimgs, dtype, ensure_ndim, memory, memory_level, auto_resample, verbose)
    410         # We check the dimensionality of the niimg
    411         try:
--> 412             niimg = check_niimg(niimg, ensure_ndim=ndim)
    413         except DimensionError as exc:
    414             # Keep track of the additional dimension in the error

/home/parietal/dbzdok/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nilearn-0.1.5.dev0-py2.7.egg/nilearn/_utils/niimg_conversions.pyc in check_niimg(niimg, ensure_ndim, atleast_4d, dtype, return_iterator, wildcards)
    253 
    254     if ensure_ndim is not None and len(niimg.shape) != ensure_ndim:
--> 255         raise DimensionError(len(niimg.shape), ensure_ndim)
    256 
    257     if return_iterator:

DimensionError: Data must be a 5D Niimg-like object but you provided a list of 3D images. See http://nilearn.github.io/building_blocks/manipulating_mr_images.html#niimg.```
``````
title: concat_imgs throws incomprehensible error for incongruent nifti shapes
concat_imgs throws incomprehensible error for incongruent nifti shapes

text: How can the message be enhanced?
For example, "You provided items of incongruent dimensionality (e.g. [3D 3d 4D]) to concatenate."
